block.p: A Skeptical Europe Awaits Bush on 5-Day Trip President Bush will arrive tomorrow in Spain to begin a five-day trip across Europe, where there is little love of America's new president and a growing perception that the United States, under his leadership, is looking out only for itself these days -- polluting the skies, breaking treaties and flirting with new arms races.

Challenge From Iran Reformists Supporters of President Mohammad Khatami's attempts to create a freer Islamic republic said his re-election victory should prompt his conservative opponents to reassess their bids to frustrate change.

U.S. Urges Mideast Cease-Fire The United States director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, sought Israeli and Palestinian approval of a formal cease-fire plan. Meanwhile, 4,000 Palestinians marched in a funeral procession for three Bedouin women who were hit by Israeli tank fire on Saturday.
Israeli officials have let loose an outpouring of resentment against Jews in the diaspora for canceling or postponing visits, fearing terrorism.

Mexican to Face U.S. Court Mario Villanueva, the former governor of the state of Quintana Roo, is likely to become the highest-ranking Latin American politician to face cocaine charges in a United States court since the 1989 arrest of Manuel Noriega. Mr. Villanueva is said to have helped smuggle 200 tons of cocaine to the United States.
Hostage Execution Postponed The Philippine government dropped its objection to bringing in a Malaysian negotiator, minutes before a deadline by Muslim separatists to behead an American hostage.

Italian Cabinet Is Named Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi formed Italy's 59th postwar government, with a cabinet that balances his need to reward political allies with his desire to reassure European partners.

Dutch Ship Offers Abortions A privately financed Dutch ship called Women on Waves, equipped to carry out abortions in international waters near countries where the practice is banned, is ready to begin its first voyage today. The first port of call will be Dublin.

Storm's Toll Is High In Texas and Louisiana Storm-weary Houston residents emerged from waterlogged homes to face highways littered with jackknifed 18-wheelers, roads lined with abandoned cars and trash, and whole neighborhoods under water. Tropical Storm Allison, which hammered the Texas and Louisiana coastlines for nearly a week, left at least 16 people dead, nearly $1 billion in estimated losses, and about 10,000 homes and 5,000 buildings damaged.
The drenched residents of southern Louisiana continued to sandbag and pray for an end to the deluge.

U.S. Lags in Climate Science In little more than a decade, the United States has fallen significantly behind other countries in its ability to simulate and predict long-term shifts in climate, according to a wide range of scientists and recent federal studies. President Bush plans to use a Rose Garden speech on global warming policy today to propose several ways to improve the situation, government officials say.

Oklahoma City After Bombing Of the myriad ways the 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building transformed Oklahoma City, perhaps one of the most unexpected and surprising is that the city is now a tourist attraction. The inevitable tension -- the fine line between remembrance and exploitation -- is hardly lost on residents.

Timothy J. McVeigh, who killed 168 people in the bombing, spent his last full day of life in a 9- by 14-foot prison holding room only steps away from the death chamber in Terre Haute, Ind., writing letters, and waiting. He was in ''amazingly good spirits,'' one of his lawyers said. ''Quite frankly, he is ready to die.''

Hog Farmers' Last Stand For a coalition of small, independent hog farmers in the Midwest, a mandatory fee assessed on hog sales that produces money for advertising pork has grown from an irritant to an emblem of a last stand against the rapid consolidation of agriculture and agribusiness that they say is driving them out of the business.

Boot Camp for Conservatives The art of selling conservatism as compassion is taught in Arlington, Va., a few miles from the White House, at boot camp for young conservatives who aspire to power. The Leadership Institute gets about $8 million a year in contributions from wealthy conservatives.

Pataki Sets Green Goals For New York State Governor Pataki ordered that state buildings get 20 percent of their electricity from renewable energy sources like solar or wind power by 2010, an effort that environmentalists lauded as the most ambitious of its kind in the country. He also appointed a task force of industry leaders, state officials and environmentalists to find ways to reduce carbon dioxide emissions in New York, to combat global warming.

Puerto Rican Day Parade The parade, in its 44th year one of New York City's largest events, swept up Fifth Avenue in a clamorous display of ethnic pride and surging political power that drew an estimated two million enthusiastic spectators and was watched over by 6,000 police officers. The extraordinary police presence had been assigned to deter any recurrence of the violence that followed last year's parade.

A Digital Dream Factory Pixar, Hollywood's most successful and trend-setting computer animation company, has built an $88 million headquarters near downtown San Francisco. It is a sign of where the future seems to be headed.
Kuerten Wins French Open Gustavo Kuerten defeated Alex Corretja, 6-7 (3), 7-5, 6-2, 6-0. The victory gave the Brazilian his second French Open title in a row, third over all.
Lakers Lead the Series Los Angeles beat the 76ers in Philadelphia, 96-91, taking a 2-1 lead in the National Basketball Association finals. Game 4 is Wednesday.
John McKay The football coach, who led the University of Southern California to four unofficial national championships, then coached the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for nine seasons, was 77.
Stephan Weiss A sculptor and painter who with his wife, Donna Karan, founded one of America's leading fashion houses, he was 62.

A Network With Chinese Ties Phoenix Satellite Television could begin broadcasting its Chinese-language news channel in Taiwan as early as July, if it wins government approval. Phoenix, based in Hong Kong, would stand apart from its rivals in one crucial respect: it is backed by the Chinese mainland.
Virgin Mobile in Sprint Deal Virgin Mobile, in its first foray in the American telecommunications market, is said to have reached a deal for a joint venture with Sprint.

Natural Gas Prices Drop The price of natural gas sold into Southern California fell sharply last week after both the free fall in electricity prices and the expiration of a controversial pipeline contract.

Koreas to Permit Road Link North and South Korea have agreed to open the first regular ground route between the two countries as a result of negotiations between top executives of the Hyundai Group and North Korean officials on reducing the cost of tours to the North.

Korean Air has canceled 80 percent of its flights scheduled tomorrow because most of its pilots plan to join a nationwide strike called by the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions. South Korea's other major airline, Asiana, was also expected to cancel many flights tomorrow because of a strike by ground crews.
